head.title: Doubling, Not Just for Blood, But for the Only Killing Lead

hedline.hl1: Doubling, Not Just for Blood, But for the Only Killing Lead

abstract.p: Alan Truscott Bridge column on mini-Lightner, less well known lead-directing double; diagrammed deal (M)

Most players are familiar with the Lightner Double, which is a move at the slam level to direct a nonobvious lead, often in dummy's suit. But the mini-Lightner, an application of the same principle at the level of four or five, is less well known.

A good example occurred in the semifinal stage of the New York Grand National Teams, played Sunday at the Town Club, 9 East 86th Street in Manhattan. North opened one club, which was artificial and usually strong. Barry Rigal, East, now ventured three clubs in the teeth of the vulnerability.
A double would have collected at least 500 for North-South, but it is not easy to penalize such bids, and North-South continued to the normal contract of four hearts.
The three-club bid had been made with the idea of suggesting a club lead, but now East changed his mind. He no longer wanted a club lead.
He produced an unexpected double, a mini-Lightner warning West against leading a club. Such doubles are nearly always based on a void somewhere, usually in dummy's original suit.

The West player, Jeff Aker, had no trouble in reading the message and deciding what to do. He carefully led the diamond two, a suit-preference request for a club return. Rigal ruffed and returned the club three, giving his partner the entry to provide a second diamond ruff.
That was three tricks for the defense, and the club ace and an eventual trump trick resulted in a two-trick penalty.
In the replay, Rigal's wife, Sue Picus, held the South cards. After her partner, Alex Ornstein, opened one diamond, East did not choose to bid, inhibited by the vulnerability.

The final contract was four hearts, and West made a ''safe'' lead of the heart queen. This proved safe for South, who made two overtricks by maneuvering to draw two rounds of trump and then discarding her club losers.
The Rigal team, which included Brady Richter and John Solodar, gained 13 imps en route to victory over a team led by Jesus Arias.

In the final this month, the Rigal team will meet Michael Polowan, Adam Wildavsky, Richard Schwartz, Robb Gordon, Zia Mahmood and David Berkowitz, who won their semifinal match against a team headed by Glenn Milgrim.
